questions.question: What is depth of field (DoF)?
options: The focal length of the lens
The range of distances that look acceptably sharp
questions.reviewHint: DoF = near-to-far zone of acceptable sharpness.

questions.question: Which aperture gives the shallowest DoF (most background blur)?
questions.reviewHint: Lower f-number = wider aperture = shallower DoF.

questions.question: Which change will NOT increase background blur?
options: Placing the subject farther from the background
questions.reviewHint: Smaller aperture (higher f-number) increases DoF, not blur.

questions.question: At the same aperture and distance, which gives a shallower DoF?
questions.reviewHint: Longer focal lengths give shallower DoF at the same distance.

questions.question: For a group portrait (two rows), which is the safest approach?
options: f/2 and focus on the front person
Use f/5.6–f/8 and focus around the front row's eyes
f/1.4 and focus on the background
questions.reviewHint: Stop down a bit for more DoF across both rows.

questions.question: Landscape with foreground rock + distant mountains—how to keep most sharp?
options: f/2 and focus on the mountains
Use ~f/8–f/11 and focus about a third into the scene
Focus on the closest rock only
questions.reviewHint: Hyperfocal-style focusing: stop down and focus ~1/3 in.

questions.question: What is a common side effect of using very small apertures (e.g., f/22)?
questions.reviewHint: Diffraction can soften fine detail at very high f-numbers.

questions.question: Bokeh refers to:
questions.reviewHint: Bokeh = how the blur looks (smooth/harsh), not just "more/less."

questions.question: For a shallow-DoF portrait, where should you place the focus point?
questions.reviewHint: Nearest eye is the priority with shallow DoF.

questions.question: In macro/very close-up work, DoF becomes:
options: Extremely thin; stop down (higher f-number) to gain depth
questions.reviewHint: Close focus = paper-thin DoF → use smaller aperture (and more light).

questions.question: As you move closer to your subject (keeping settings the same), DoF:
At the same framing and f-number, a full-frame camera typically gives:
questions.reviewHint: Matching framing often means closer/longer on full-frame → shallower DoF.

questions.question: Changing from f/4 to f/8 (no other changes) will:
options: Decrease DoF and brighten by 2 stops
Increase DoF and darken by 2 stops
Reduce motion blur at the same shutter speed
questions.reviewHint: Higher f-number = more DoF and less light (adjust shutter/ISO).

questions.question: It's bright midday and you want f/1.4 for creamy background but you're already at 1/8000 s, ISO 100. What helps?
options: Add an ND filter to keep exposure while staying at f/1.4
questions.reviewHint: ND filter cuts light so you can keep wide aperture for blur.
